1.verse: James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes in the dispersion: Greetings.

2.verse: Consider it sheer joy, my brothers, when you encounter various kinds of trials,

3.verse: because you know that the testing of your faith produces endurance.

4.verse: And let endurance carry out its intended purpose, so that you may be mature and complete, lacking in nothing.

5.verse: But if any of you lacks wisdom, he should ask God, who gives to everyone generously, not demanding something in return, and it will be given to him.

6.verse: But he must ask in faith without doubting, for the doubter is like a wave of the sea, driven by the wind and tossed about.

7.verse: For that person must not imagine that he will receive anything from the Lord;

8.verse: he is a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways.

9.verse: Let the brother of limited means take pride in his high position,

10.verse: and the wealthy brother in his humiliation, because like a flower in the meadow he will pass away.

11.verse: For the sun rises with its scorching heat and withers the meadow; its flower falls and its beauty fades. In the same way the rich man will fade away while pursuing his business.

12.verse: Blessed is the man who remains steadfast when tested, because once he is shown to be genuine, he will receive the crown of life that the Lord has promised to those who love him.

13.verse: No one when tempted should say, “I am being tempted by God”; for God cannot be tempted to do evil, and he himself tempts no one else.

14.verse: But each person is tempted when by his own desire he is lured away and enticed.

15.verse: Then desire, when it has conceived, gives birth to sin; and sin, when it is full-grown, brings forth death.

16.verse: Do not be deceived, my dear brothers.

17.verse: Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow caused by change.

18.verse: According to his sovereign plan, he brought us into being through his word of truth, so that we would be a kind of first fruits of all he created.

19.verse: Understand this, my dear brothers: everyone must be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to become angry.

20.verse: For the anger of man does not bring about the righteousness that God requires.

21.verse: Therefore put aside all filthiness and rampant wickedness, and receive with meekness the implanted word, which is able to save your souls.

22.verse: But be doers of the word and not merely hearers, deceiving yourselves.

23.verse: For if someone is a hearer of the word and not a doer, he is like a person who looks at his natural face in a mirror;

24.verse: then after looking at himself he goes away and immediately forgets what he was like.

25.verse: But the person who looks intently into the perfect law, the law that provides liberty, and continues in it, not having become a forgetful hearer but an active doer—he will be blessed in his doing.

26.verse: If someone thinks that he is religious, yet does not bridle his tongue but deceives his heart, this person’s religion is worthless.

27.verse: Religion that is pure and undefiled before God the Father is this: to care for orphans and widows in their time of trouble, and to keep oneself unstained by the world.

1.verse: My brothers, stop showing favoritism as you live out your faith in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ.

2.verse: For if a man comes into your congregation wearing a gold ring and fine clothes, and a poor man in dirty clothes also comes in,

3.verse: and you pay special attention to the one wearing the fine clothes and say, “You sit here in a good place,” but to the poor man you say, “You stand over there, or sit down here at my feet,”

4.verse: have you not made distinctions among yourselves and become judges with evil motives?

5.verse: Listen, my dear brothers! Did not God choose those whom the world considers poor to be rich in faith and to inherit the kingdom, which he promised to those who love him?

6.verse: But you have dishonored the poor! Is it not the rich who oppress you? And are not they the ones who drag you into court?

7.verse: Are they not the ones who are blaspheming the honorable name by which you were called?

8.verse: If you really fulfill the royal law as set forth in this scripture, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself,” you are doing well.

9.verse: But if you show favoritism, you are committing sin and are convicted by the law as transgressors.

10.verse: For whoever keeps the entire law yet fails at a single point has become guilty of the law as a whole.

11.verse: For he who said, “Do not commit adultery,” also said, “Do not commit murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery but do commit murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.

12.verse: So speak and so act as those who are to be judged by the law that brings freedom.

13.verse: For judgment will be without mercy for one who has shown no mercy; mercy triumphs over judgment.

14.verse: What good is it, my brothers, if someone claims to have faith but has no works? Can that kind of faith save him?

15.verse: If a brother or sister lacks adequate clothing and is in need of daily food,

16.verse: and one of you says to them, “Go in peace; stay warm and eat your fill,” and yet you do not give them what their body needs, what good is that?

17.verse: In the same way faith, if it has no works, is dead, since it is by itself.

18.verse: But someone will say, “You have faith and I have works.” Show me your faith without works, and I will show you my faith by my works.

19.verse: You believe that God is one; you do well. Even the demons believe, and shudder.

20.verse: Would you like to be shown, you shallow person, that faith without works is useless?

21.verse: Was not Abraham our father justified by works when he offered his son Isaac on the altar?

22.verse: You see that faith was at work along with his works and that his faith was made complete by his works.

23.verse: And the scripture was fulfilled that says, “And Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness,” and he was called the friend of God.

24.verse: You see that a person is justified by works and not by faith alone.

25.verse: And in the same way was not also Rahab the harlot justified by works when she took in the spies and sent them out by another way?

26.verse: For just as the body without the spirit is dead, so also faith devoid of works is dead.

1.verse: Not many of you should become teachers, my brothers, for you know that those of us who teach will be judged by a stricter standard.

2.verse: For we all stumble in many ways. If someone does not stumble in what he says, he is a mature individual, able to bridle his whole body as well.

3.verse: Now if we put bits into the mouths of horses to make them obey us, then we guide their entire body.

4.verse: Or consider ships: though they are so large and are driven by strong winds, they are steered by a very small rudder, wherever the impulse of the pilot directs.

5.verse: So also is the tongue a small member, yet it boasts of great things. See how large a forest is set on fire by such a small flame.

6.verse: And the tongue is a fire! The tongue is a world of iniquity set among our members; it defiles the whole body, sets on fire the course of our life, and is set on fire by hell.

7.verse: For every species of beast and bird, reptile and sea creature, can be tamed, and has been tamed by the human species.

8.verse: But the tongue, no one is able to tame; it is a restless evil, full of deadly poison.

9.verse: With it we bless our Lord and Father, and with it we curse those who are made in the likeness of God.

10.verse: From the same mouth come blessing and cursing. My brothers, this should not happen.

11.verse: Does a spring pour forth water from the same opening that is both fresh and brackish?

12.verse: My brothers, can a fig tree produce olives, or a grapevine figs? Neither can a salt spring supply fresh water.

13.verse: Who is wise and understanding among you? By his exemplary conduct let him show his works done in the gentleness born of wisdom.

14.verse: But if you have bitter jealousy and selfish ambition in your heart, do not be arrogant and tell lies against the truth.

15.verse: This is not the wisdom that comes down from above, but is earthly, unspiritual, demonic.

16.verse: For where jealousy and selfish ambition exist, there you will find disorder and every evil practice.

17.verse: But the wisdom from above is first of all pure, then peaceable, gentle, open to reason, full of mercy and good fruits, free from prejudice and hypocrisy.

18.verse: And a harvest of righteousness is sown in peace by those who make peace.

1.verse: What accounts for the quarrels and disputes among you? Is it not this—your desires that are at war in your members?

2.verse: You desire and do not have; you murder and envy and cannot obtain; you fight and quarrel. You do not have because you do not ask.

3.verse: You ask and do not receive because you ask for the wrong reason, that you can spend it on your pleasures.

4.verse: You adulterous people! Do you not know that friendship with the world is hostility toward God? Therefore whoever desires to be a friend of the world makes himself an enemy of God.

5.verse: Or do you imagine that scripture has no meaning when it says, “God yearns jealously over the spirit that he has placed in us”?

6.verse: But he gives greater grace. That is why scripture says, “God opposes the proud but he gives grace to the humble.”

7.verse: So submit yourselves to God. Resist the devil and he will flee from you.

8.verse: Draw near to God and he will draw near to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners, and purify your hearts, you double-minded.

9.verse: Be miserable and mourn and weep; let your laughter be turned into mourning and your joy into gloom.

10.verse: Humble yourselves in the presence of the Lord and he will lift you up.

11.verse: Do not speak against one another, my brothers. Whoever speaks against a brother or judges his brother, speaks against the law and judges the law; but if you judge the law, you are not a doer of the law but a judge of it.

12.verse: There is only one who is the lawgiver and judge—the one who is able to save and to destroy; so who are you to be judging your neighbor?

13.verse: Come now, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will go to some city and spend a year there and engage in business and make a profit.”

14.verse: You have no idea what your life will be like tomorrow. For you are but a mist that appears for a brief moment and then disappears.

15.verse: Instead, you ought to say, “If the Lord so decrees, then we will live and do this or that.”

16.verse: But as it is, you are making arrogant boasts; all such boasting is evil.

17.verse: So the person who knows what is right to do and fails to do it, for him it is sin.

1.verse: Come now, you rich people, weep and wail over the miseries that are coming your way.

2.verse: Your riches have rotted and your clothes are moth-eaten.

3.verse: Your gold and your silver have rusted and their rust will be a witness against you, and it will consume your flesh like fire. You have stored up treasure for the last days.

4.verse: Look, the wages you have held back from the workers who mowed your fields are crying out against you, and the cries of the harvesters have reached the ears of the Lord of Hosts.

5.verse: You have lived on the earth in self-indulgence and luxury. You have fattened your hearts for a day of slaughter.

6.verse: You condemn the innocent and put him to death; he does not resist you.

7.verse: Be patient, therefore, dear friends, until the coming of the Lord. Note how the farmer waits for the precious harvest of the earth, being patient for it until it receives the early and latter rains.

8.verse: You too must be patient; strengthen your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is near.

9.verse: Do not complain against one another, my brothers, lest you be judged. Look, the judge is standing at the doors.

10.verse: As an example of suffering and patience, brothers, take the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.

11.verse: For sure, we regard as blessed those who persevered. You have heard of the perseverance of Job and have seen the result of the Lord's activity, that the Lord is exceedingly compassionate and merciful.

12.verse: Above all, my brothers, do not swear, either by heaven or by earth or by any other oath. Rather let your “Yes” be yes and your “No,” no, so that you may not fall under judgment.

13.verse: Is anyone among you suffering? He should pray. Is anyone cheerful? He should sing praises.

14.verse: Is anyone among you sick? He should call for the elders of the church and have them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord;

15.verse: and the prayer offered in faith will restore the one who is sick and the Lord will raise him up. And if he has committed sins, he will be forgiven.

16.verse: Therefore confess your sins to one another and pray for one another so that you may be healed. The active prayer of a righteous person has great power.

17.verse: Elijah was a man exactly like us, and he prayed earnestly that it would not rain, and for three years and six months no rain fell on the earth.

18.verse: Then he prayed again, and the heavens poured down rain and the earth produced its harvest.

19.verse: My brothers, if anyone among you strays from the truth and someone brings him back,

20.verse: he should know that the one who brings a sinner back from the error of his way will save that person’s soul from death and cover a multitude of sins.
